awd_titl_txt: Conference: Symposium on Plant Protein Phosphorylation, May 26-28, Columbia, MO
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit
Protein phosphorylation is an enzyme mediated reaction in which a phosphate is added to a protein to alter its function. Protein phosphorylation and dephosphorylation play key roles in many aspects of plant biology, including control of cell division, pathways of carbon and nitrogen metabolism, pattern formation, hormonal responses, and abiotic and biotic responses to environmental signals. The 2010 Symposium on Plant Protein Phosphorylation, which will be held from May 26-28, 2010, on the Columbia campus of the University of Missouri, represents the only U.S. meeting to focus on this fundamental biochemical process as a unifying theme. The symposium will provide an interdisciplinary venue in which scholars studying protein modification, as it relates to a broad range of biological questions and using a variety of plant species, can meet and share their research. It also will provide a unique international forum to examine challenges and emerging paradigms in studies of protein phosphorylation. The symposium will be organized to promote interactions across disciplines in hopes of stimulating new research collaborations. Emphasis will also be placed on inclusion of young investigators,as speakers, poster presenters, and attendees. The symposium, which is expected to draw between 200 and 250 worldwide participants, is a unique opportunity to facilitate rapid dissemination of acquired knowledge and technical expertise regarding protein phosphorylation in plants.

Broader Impacts
Because protein phosphorylation is critical to many aspects of plant biology a better understanding of this post-translational control mechanism will contribute the production of crops with higher yields and insights into how plants might cope with a changing environment. The Symposium on Plant Protein Phosphorylation will bring together a diverse group of international scholars studying a fundamental biological process in plants from varying disciplinary angles. In so doing, this symposium will provide a unique platform from which research between disciplines can flow and interact. Organized and hosted by the Interdisciplinary Plant Group at the University of Missouri every three years since 1990, the symposium will include a concerted effort to broaden participation of undergraduate students, particularly those from smaller and minority-serving institutions, as well as female research scientists. The symposium also will enhance networking opportunities for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and will create a venue to foster collaborative and interdisciplinary research projects for faculty and students.

por.por_cntn:
Plant growth and development are controlled by many complex cellular-level processes. One such process is protein phosphorylation, which involves the modification of a protein by the attachment of a phosphate. The result of protein phosphorylation is often the alteration of enzymes, or the proteins that catalyze biochemical reactions. Knowledge of how protein phosphorylation works is important for understanding fundamental processes of plants, such as how they convert energy from the sun into sugar for themselves, how they metabolize the macronutrients carbon and nitrogen, how cell division is controlled, and how plants are able to respond to cues from their environment. The Symposium on Plant Protein Phosphorylation was hosted on the Columbia campus of the University of Missouri from May 26-28, 2010. The Symposium brought together twenty-three world-renowned scientists to share recent breakthroughs in the area of protein phosphorylation in plants. The Symposium was attended by 165 students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty, government scientists, and representatives from different ag-biotech industries. This conference was the tenth international Symposium on Plant Protein Phosphorylation and the seventh one hosted at the University of Missouri.

Funding from the National Science Foundation was used to help broaden the participation of students and postdoctoral fellows, particularly undergraduate students from small Midwestern institutions. Of the 165 attendees, 67 were students and postdoctoral fellows. Nine undergraduate students and two faculty mentors received travel stipends to attend the Symposium. These students represented Pittsburgh State University (KS), Mississippi State University, University of Arizona, College of St. Benedict/St. John's University (MN), Lawrence University (WI), Grinnell College (IA), and Baker University (KS). Three of these undergraduate students attended the Symposium and then stayed on to complete summer research internships in plant biology laboratories at the University of Missouri.

 The Symposium exposed attendees to the latest breakthroughs in the area of plant protein phosphorylation and to a diverse set of approaches being used to study this important biological phenomenon. The Symposium advances discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training, and learning by incorporating undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows in the events, through poster sessions, presentations, and mentoring opportunities. It broadens the participation of underrepresented groups by specifically recruiting students from small Midwestern and minority institutions. Women also played a significant role as speakers in the Symposium; of the twenty-three speakers, ten were women, seven of which are early career academics. Participation in professional meetings, such as this, is important for the advancement of women in science, as it gives their work greater visibility and expands their professional networks, two qualities considered in tenure and promotion reviews. The Symposium enhances the research and education infrastructure of the University of Missouri in the area of the plant sciences by providing an opportunity for MU faculty and students to share their research and to establish collaborations with scientists at other institutions.
